Transition Tufnell Park is part of the Transition Network, facing up to climate change and building a stronger community in Tufnell Park

19 Jul: Crude Awakening: The Oil Crash

7pm at the Lord Palmerston


Crude Awakening: The Oil Crash, produced and directed by award-winning European journalists and filmmakers Basil Gelpke and Ray McCormack, tells the story of how our civilization’s addiction to oil puts it on a collision course with geology. Compelling, intelligent, and highly entertaining, the film visits with the world’s top experts and comes to a startling, but logical conclusion – our industrial society, built on cheap and readily available oil, must be completely re-imagined and overhauled.

Come and join us upstairs at the Lord Palmerston to see this inspiring film.

Upstairs at the Lord Palmerston,
33 Dartmouth Park Hill, NW5 1HU.
7pm, Thursday 19th July.

An event organized jointly with Transitions Tufnell Park, Kentish Town and Dartmouth Park.

03 Jul: Knitting on Tuesday

Our first knitting and sewing group meet up


When? Tuesday 3rd July at 6pm

Where? Cafe Rustique, 142, Fortress Road

Who? Anybody at all, of any experience. There will be lots of beginners!

Materials for beginners will be provided.

30 Jun: At the Farmer's Market

Tufnell Park School HSA

Tufnell Park School Home School Association will be selling raffle tickets and explaining their Playground Project and other ideas at the Tufnell Park Tavern Farmer’s Market this coming Saturday, the 30th, between 1100 and 1500 hours.

If anyone would like to help out with a stint on the stall let them know at tpshsan7@gmail.com.

27 Jun: Secret Garden update

Early last spring, Transition Tufnell Park was given the opportunity by Penny Cloutte to transform her garden from a wilderness to a flourishing group garden. Working together, the plot which was full of brambles, weeds and debris has become, over the year a productive, communal, fruit and vegetable garden. The group meet monthly with a more frequent watering and weeding rota in summer. The garden is unbelievably productive with plenty for all to share; chard, onions, potatoes, carrots, tomatoes, beans and more. In November we added fruit trees and this spring, a herb garden and pond.

Part of the garden’s success has been the friendship and camaraderie which has built up around the activity. There is always lashings of tea and cake when we meet, friendship to grow as well as the vegetables and we have great fun.

Pictures here.
